message.content: This question requires an understanding of the concept of conservation, which refers to the responsible and sustainable use of resources. Option (C) is the correct answer because taking shorter showers is an example of conserving water, which is a valuable resource. Option (A) is incorrect because smoke stacks are associated with air pollution and do not align with conservation. Option (B) is incorrect because littering is the opposite of conservation and contributes to environmental degradation. Option (D) is incorrect because car travel is not inherently conservation-oriented, although carpooling or using public transportation would be examples of conservation.

This question requires an understanding of the concept of conservation, which is the practice of using resources wisely and minimizing waste. Option (C), shorter showers, is a good example of conservation because it involves reducing the amount of water used, thus conserving a valuable resource. Option (A), smoke stacks, is incorrect because it is related to industrial pollution and not conservation. Option (B), littering, is also incorrect because it involves the careless disposal of waste. Option (D), car travel, is too broad and does not specifically address conservation.

Conservation generally refers to the responsible and sustainable use of natural resources. Option (A), smoke stacks, is incorrect because smoke stacks are associated with pollution and the release of harmful substances into the environment. Option (B), littering, is also incorrect because littering is the opposite of conservation and contributes to pollution and degradation of the environment. Option (D), car travel, is not a good example of conservation because vehicle emissions contribute to air pollution and the consumption of fossil fuels. Option (C), shorter showers, is a good example of conservation because it involves reducing water usage, which is an important natural resource. Shortening showers helps to conserve water and reduce water waste, promoting sustainability and responsible resource management.
